NIST CISO 800-53 RMF I found this video incredibly insightful and thought-provoking. The discussion on the value of certifications, particularly CompTIA Security Plus, was enlightening. I appreciate how you emphasized the importance of considering certifications as just one aspect of a holistic set of skills and qualifications. The analogy of treating yourself as a character in an RPG game and acquiring different "stats" was a unique and effective way to convey the idea. Your breakdown of the various stats, such as consistency, communication, technical ability, and formal education, provided a clear framework for evaluating one's readiness for a career in cybersecurity. The comparison between Security Plus and Google's cyber security program was also intriguing, highlighting each option's strengths and considerations. Thank you for sharing this valuable information!

Secret Word: NIST  (comment #1) Hey Josh, Thank you for all the videos and content you share with us. I have recently embarked on transitioning into an IT career and while my experience is next to nothing, I do agree with the points you made. I was enrolled in a scholarship bootcamp where I completed my SANS sec401 certification. Prior to this, I was self studying for security+ exam. I realized that sans course was more hands on with various labs whereas security+ was entirely a MCQ style format. I was super confident upon completing my sec401 with Sans and proudly put it on my resume only to realize that it was not one of the certs that would make it through the 'gatekeepers'. I barely have secured any interview in the past 2 months and the ones I did, the recruiters were not too keen of the sec401 and most have not heard of it. I get it, not a lot of people actually opt for those certs because of the price point but, it is a bit frustrating at the same time when you can't make it past the gatekeepers and now have to go back to getting a cert that may not help me achieve a higher skill set but will most likely make it through the gatekeepers. I see that you make the same point about google's cybersecurity cert..this whole journey of breaking into IT can be a bit frustrating for those that are making transition into IT with no prior IT experience. >_<
NIST					  Security+ certification can help individuals gain a better understanding of cybersecurity concepts, terminology, and best practices, which can be valuable in day-to-day work.

NIST I believe that combining certifications with hands-on experience and the practical application of skills is often the most effective approach to building a successful career in a specific field, whether you choose CompTIA Security or a Google cert. NIST  I believe this video provides a great example of comparing and contrasting two sides of cybersecurity, helping to dismiss some initial myths I had about certifications. It also opened my eyes to alternative routes I can explore in my journey to break into the field of cybersecurity.

NIST  I would definitely agree with your opinion on the Security+ and other IT certs not necessarily reflecting that you have the skills to do a certain job or task. I studied for the Security+ for about a month and passed this past February, but I wouldn't say I am capable of defending an enterprise network. However, the Security+ did give me better insight into the duties and responsibilities of cybersecurity workers, the threats they may deal with, and the tools used to protect systems and networks from those threats. It definitely looks great on a resume though, landing my first IT job with a company partially thanks to my CompTIA trifecta. (I got the A+ and Net+ paid for via Career and Technical Education courses at my high school.)

NIST  I agree with you that Security+ isn't necessary, but I don't think it's all bad. I think the issue is, it isn't really a cybersecurity certification. To me, its more like ensuring that entry level IT professionals conduct themselves with security in mind.
